solution.text:
Total surface area of all the cubes \(= 5 \times 6 \times 2.7^2 = 218.7 cm^2\)
Area of each face =\(2.7^2 cm^2\)
Number of faces that face inward = 10 faces
Therefore, outer surface area = 218.7 - 72.9 = 145.8 \(cm^2\)
Cost of paint = Rs 12 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(145.8 \times 12\)
= Rs. 1749.6

content.text: Five cubes of edge 2.7 cm each are placed side by side and stuck together as shown. The cost of painting is Rs 12 per \(cm^2\). What is the cost of painting the outer surface of the entire object?

hint.text: Count the number of faces that are outward facing

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 139 \times 30 + \frac 12 \times 53\times(139 + 109)\)
\(= 10742 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 5 km/hr = 5000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 10742 \times 5000 = 53710000 m^3/hr\)
= 53710 megalitre/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7\) hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 53710\)
= 9023280 megalitres

content.text: The Vashishti river flows into the Arabian Sea. The cross-section of the river can be approximated as the shape shown in the diagram below. What volume of water (in megalitres) flows into the sea over the course of a week? Note that 1 megalitre = 1000000 litres

Therefore, number of bricks required \(= 20 \times \frac{1000000}{1000}\)
\(= 20000\)

Volume = Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder

solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\pi \times \frac{26}2 \times 3 + 2 \pi \times \frac{9}2 \times 3 + 2\pi({\frac{26}2}^2 - {\frac{9}2}^2)\)
= 1265\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 1265 \times 0.2\)
= Rs. 253

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \((\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h)\)
\(= 4554 cm^3\)
Now, Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = (\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h) = (\pi (\frac {10}{2})^2 \times x) - (\pi (\frac {10}{2} - 5)^2 \times x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac {10}2)^2-\pi (\frac {10}2 - m)^2}\)
= 57.96 cm

content.text: The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 936 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid?
What is the Breadth of the cuboid?

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \(936 m^2\)
Therefore, \(936 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{936}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{9}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 3 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid?

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

solution.text:
Area of school floor \(= 7293 m^2\)
Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 17 \times 13 = 221 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 330000

content.text: The area of your school library floor is \(7293 m^2\). You are asked to use tiles in the shape of a parallelogram with a base of 17 cm and a height of 13 cm to cover the floor. How many such tiles will you need to purchase? You can break the tiles in any way to cover the entire floor.

hint.text: Start by finding the area of each tile.

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 1848\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{1848}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area of Base = \(\pi r^2 = \frac{1848}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {1848\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 14 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 7 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 4312 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 1848 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 15^2 \times 43 = 30407.14 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = 30407.14 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 27 \times 18 \times h = 30407.14 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {30407.14}{27 \times 18} = 62.57\)
The new cuboid is 62.57 cm tall

=\(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\times 1600 cm^2\)
Therefore, volume of water added = Area of base \(\times\) Rise in water Level
=103800 \(cm^3\)
Since 1L =\(1000cm^3\)
Volume of water added = 103.8 L

content.text: The water tank in Rekha’s house has a base in the shape of an equilateral triangle with each side measuring 40 cm. It is filled with water till a height of 3 metres. She pours some more water into the tank and the new level is 4.5 metres. What volume of water did she pour into the tank? Use \(\sqrt{3} = 1.73\)

hint.text: Area of an equilateral triangle = \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times side^2\)

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 7854 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be \(x\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (10)^2 \times 49 - \pi (10-x)^2 \times 49\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{49\pi}=10^2 - (10-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (10-x)^2 = 100 - \frac{V}{49\pi}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 10 - 7\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3\)
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

content.text: The volume of a metallic cylinder pipe is 7854 cubic centimetres. Its length is 49 cm and its external radius is 10 cm. Find its thickness

content.text: Rajiv likes to make 3D shapes from paper. Yesterday, he started with a rectangular piece of paper of length 24 cm and breadth 14 cm. He then rolled the paper into a cylinder so that the cylinder is now 24 cm long. What is the volume of the air inside the cylinder so formed?

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 66 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{66}{\pi} = 21 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 66 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 66 + 21\)
= 27.6 \(cm^2\)

content.text: You are given a cylindrical cake with icing on the top and bottom. There is no icing on the curved surface and the curved surface area is \(66 cm^2\). solution.text:
Volume of pipe=Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder
\(= \pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(= \pi (19)^2 \times 36 - \pi(15)^2 \times 36\)
= 15387.43\( cm^3\)
\(Mass = Volume \times Density\)
\(\Rightarrow Mass = 15387.43 cm^3 \times \frac{8.6 g}{cm^3}\)
= 132331.89 g

solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Trapezium (2) + Area of Triangle (3) + Area of Triangle (4) + Area of Triangle (5)
\(\frac 12 \times a \times b + \frac 12 (b + e)(c + d) + \frac 12 \times e \times f + \frac 12 \times g \times (d+f) + \frac 12 \times (a+c) \times g\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 40 \times 41 + \frac 12 \times 91 \times 61 + \frac 12 \times 50 \times 30 + \frac 12 \times 40 \times 50 + \frac 12 \times 81 \times 40\)
\(=7365.5 cm^2\)

\(= \frac 12 (a+c)(h) \times 2\)
\(= \frac 12 (4.5 + 6)(3) \times 2\)
\(= 31.5 mm^2\)
